citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility has not developed or discussed a care plan for the goats with the attending veterinarian. The current diet as
well as deworming plan were not discussed with the attending veterinarian and a hoof care plan has not been developed.
A complete care plan approved by the attending veterinarian is necessary in order to assure the health and well-being of
the goats. The facility in conjunction with the attending veterinarian must establish and maintain a program of adequate
veterinary care for the goats that includes appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases. Correct
by May 8, 2023.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The written Program of Veterinary Care form as well as the acquisition information for the rabbits were not available for
review during inspection. Facility representatives were unable to locate the forms, explaining that they are being kept by
an employee currently on leave. The acquisition information for all animals should be kept on hand in order to allow for
traceback while the written Program of Veterinary Care should be kept available as a reference for the facility staff if
needed for the care of the animals. The licensee shall, during business hours, have all required records available for
inspection. Correct by May 24, 2023.

The enclosures, food, and water containers for 3 rabbits are cleaned regularly but they are not being sanitized. Without
sanitization there is a higher risk of large numbers of harmful germs remaining on the surfaces which creates a health
hazard for the rabbits. Sanitization can be achieved by washing with hot water (180 °F) and soap or detergent as in a
mechanical cage washer, or by washing all soiled surfaces with a detergent solution followed by a safe and effective
disinfectant, or by cleaning all soiled surfaces with live steam or flame. Primary enclosures must be sanitized at least once
every 30 days while food and water receptacles must be done at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by May 8, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
